conclusion: A scientific research team has developed a detector whose speed can be adjusted according to its motion.
The image shows a line segment on the x-axis from point O to point B, with points A and B marked along this segment.
The velocity of the detector is inversely proportional to its displacement, so we have \\( v = \frac{k}{x} \\), where \\( k \\) is a constant.
At point A, the velocity \\( v_A = 4 \, \text{m/s} \\), so \\( 4 = \frac{k}{x_A} \\). Solving for \\( k \\), we get \\( k = 4x_A \\).
At point B, the velocity \\( v_B = 2 \, \text{m/s} \\), so \\( 2 = \frac{k}{x_B} \\). Substituting \\( k = 4x_A \\), we have \\( 2 = \frac{4x_A}{x_B} \\).
Given \\( x_B = 2 \, \text{m} \\), we solve for \\( x_A \\): \\( 2 = \frac{4x_A}{2} \\) implies \\( x_A = 1 \, \text{m} \\).
The time taken for the detector to move from point A to point B is given by \\( t = \frac{x_B - x_A}{v_A} \\).
Substituting the known values, we have \\( t = \frac{2 - 1}{4} = \frac{1}{4} \, \text{seconds} \\).
The time it takes for the detector to move from point A to point B is 0.25 seconds.
